0.body: This guide introduces developers to Bevy's ECS component, by porting the game written for Hands-on Rust: Effective Learning through 2D Game Development and Play to Bevy's ECS.
0.title: Introduction

1.body: The book (and the source project ) are structured as a series of incremental steps, leading to a full game. In the Rust ports repository , I've made minor cleanups and restructures to the source project; the locations of the projects are: port project source project The steps have been numbered (and have matching names in the source/port), in order to facilitate sequential examination and comparison. This book presents multiple chapters for each step, explaining the concepts involved. When reading a chapter, one can compare the source step with the ported one, and/or with the previous step in the respective project. The starting chapter is 06.01, where an ECS is introduced in the design. It's technically possible to read this book standalone, without the source one, but for newcomers to ECS, it's not advised, as this book won't explain the ECS concepts (only their Bevy API implementation).
1.breadcrumbs: Introduction » How to approach this book
1.title: How to approach this book

10.body:
In Bevy, components must derive Component: #[derive(Component)]
pub struct Render { pub color: ColorPair, pub glyph: FontCharType,
} #[derive(Component)]
pub struct Player; #[derive(Component)]
pub struct PointC(pub Point); There's something interesting here: PointC, which is a tuple struct, unlike the other (regular) structs. Why so? Because the type Point is not defined in our crate, and therefore, can't derive Component; in order to work this problem around, we wrap it in our type (PointC), and derive the wrapping type.
10.title: Components

11.body: Resources, differently from components, currently (this may change in the future!) don't need to be derived; anything inserted in Bevy's ECS is a resource: // WRITEME
11.title: Resources

2.body: The Bevy used version is 0.7.0; all the API links refer to the tag v0.7.0 in Bevy's repository .
2.title: References

3.body: Since comparison is a foundation of this book, I've maintained high and low-level structures as similar as I could; the most radical divergence is due to Bevy's state management. There are still a few differences, but they're minor.
3.title: Port style
